moves.3. Bc4: The bishop's gambit.   White intends for as much attack as possible.
moves.3... Nc6 4. d4: Still opening up the center; helping develop the bishop.  Better is Nf3
moves.5... Bd6 6. Nf3: Developing the knight and putting pressure on e5...also prevents Qh4
moves.6... f6: ?? a poor move...   an attempt to prevent e5
moves.7. O-O: Safeguarding the king and putting the rook on the empty file for a hopeful attack.    it's funny too, i seem to mostly use castling as an attacking move in my games. "castling is an attacking move"
moves.7... Na5: Pushing the bishop off of the dangerous diaganol
moves.8. Bd3 g5: an attempt to keep an attack on white, but black's pieces are poorly developed and soon exposed
moves.9. Nxg5: White hopes to crush the king's side and end the game quickly
moves.10. Qh5+: and white leads into the attack
moves.10... Kf8: Ke7 and white plays e5; winning the bishop
moves.11. e5: white must remove the pawn duo
moves.11... Be7 12. Bxf4: white continually sacrifices pieces to keep the pressure on black and to keep the poorly placed pieces on poorly kept squares
moves.13... Bf6 14. Nd2: here white attempts to bring the knight into play and also create a battery on the f file
moves.14... d5: black tries to refute the knight, but cannot stop the following moves
moves.16. Rf1: white wins back a piece and brings in more attack
moves.18... Nc6: the only square available  Nc4 loses to Nxc4 dx4 and Bxc4 !
moves.19. Ne4: again white brings more pieces into the fray.  also as previously stated, dxe4 loses to Bc4 !
moves.19... Bd7: an attempt to allow the a rook into play and perhaps an attempt to drive back the white queen
moves.20. Ng5 Be8: attempts to push back the white queen and release pressure, but it is too late
moves.22. Ne6: white puts the knight into an even more dangerous place.  with the obvious attack of Qg5
moves.22... Bg6: the only way to prevent the attack...
moves.23. Qg5: but white continues the same plan causing the bishop to be pinned.  Black also must be weary of Rxg6
moves.23... Qxe6: black merely stalls out the game
moves.24. Rxe6 Rf8: Black has no remaining hope and resigns  25. Rxg6  hxg6 26. Qxg6#  or  25. Rg6  Kf7 26. Qf6  Ke8 27. Qe6  Kd8 28. Rg7 and black loses much material and is mated soon after
